Core Course: Macroeconomic Management: New Methods and Current Policy Issues
Ray C. Rist WBI Evaluation Unit World Bank Fumika Ouchi Advisor Evaluation Analyst (202) 458-5625 (202) 473-5085
Number 8 August 1998
Agenor, Pierre-Richard (Notation: The World Bank Institute was formerly called the Economic Development Institute (EDI), as reflected in some text)
The Macroeconomic Management and Policy Division of EDI (EDIMP) conducted a core course on Macroeconomic Management: New Methods and Current Policy Issues in Nairobi, Kenya from April 20-30, 1998. This was the second session of the course offered in 1998. The same course was held earlier in Washington, D.C. The ten-day program was designed to provide participants with knowledge in and techniques of macroeconomic analysis of policy issues in developing economies. The course focused on recent analytical and methodological advances in the area of development macroeconomics, various quantitative methods, and discussions of policy issues. Thirty-three participants attended this course, consisting primarily of professional macroeconomists from academia, government, and multilateral institutions.
The course was evaluated by the EDI Evaluation Unit (EDIES) using an end-of-course questionnaire. The questionnaire was completed by twenty-five respondents, 75.8 percent of the total number of participants. There were two sections in the questionnaire. The first section asked respondents to rate the extent to which the course met its performance objectives. The second section asked the level of respondents knowledge about topics covered in the course, before and after completing the course, based on self-assessment. A 5-point Likert type scale that ranged from 1 = minimum to 5 = maximum was used to rate respondents rating for each question. Following are some of the major evaluation findings.
l The mean scores of all course performance indicators, including course effectiveness, design, and presenters' communication skills, exceeded 3.0, the mid-point of the 5- point scale. Respondents indicated that the course was highly relevant to their current work or functions. Respondents' mean score for this indicator was 4.6 out of 5.0, the highest rating in this evaluation.
l Results indicated that the course received very high performance ratings in three other areas. Respondents felt that the materials provided in the course were useful, and that the course helped participants find new sources of information for the future work. Overall, respondents felt that the course was a worthwhile use of their time. Over 90 percent of respondents' ratings on these three indicators fell between 4.0-5.0. The three mean scores ranged between 4.4 and 4.6 out of 5.0.
l On the level of course coverage, respondents' ratings of whether the issues were treated in sufficient depth had a mean score of 3.84 out of 5.0. Respondents were also asked whether the time between topics was effectively balanced. The mean score of the allocation of time on different topics was 3.4 out of 5.0, the lowest rating of the course performance indicators.
l Relatively lower mean scores were observed in the effectiveness of the course in the  area of understanding policy issues. Respondents mean scores of the indicators that asked the extent to which the course helped them better assess the requirements of different policy alternatives or their consequences were in the 3.5-3.6 range out of 5.0.
lPre/post knowledge assessment showed overall positive gains in respondents' level of understanding. Pre-course mean scores of all topics covered in the course were in the rage of 2.5-3.9 out of 5.0. Post-course mean scores increased to the 3.4-4.4 range, indicating that respondents felt they learned from the course and had a better understanding of these topics after the course.
lThe largest percentage gains in the level of respondents understanding were observed on the topics of financial liberalization and sequencing of reforms, vector autoregression (VAR) techniques and application, and exchange rate and currency crises. Post-course mean scores of these topics increased by 30-36 percent. Issues in fiscal policy and monetary policy had the lowest gains, 7-9 percentage changes. Relatively high pre-course ratings on policy issues, 3.6-3.9, suggest that the respondents had a fair understanding of the issues before the course and that the amount of information they gained from the course was limited.
lInformation obtained from pre/post self-assessment reflects the degree to which respondents believed they understood the topics, but does not measure how much they actually learned. The percentage changes in knowledge levels should be therefore interpreted with caution.
lA question of validity in the use of current pre/post learning measures was raised in the evaluation. Post-course knowledge ratings of four respondents were lower than their pre-course ratings, causing negative changes in pre/post comparisons. A possible explanation of this would be that having completed the course, the respondents realized they knew much less than they thought they knew, thereby rating lower scales. This indicator may need to be reviewed so that respondents can correctly interpret the question and the indicator captures what it aims to measure, namely, the level of knowledge gains from the course.
